questions.question:
Question 1: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER with a nose bleed secondary to trauma. The bleeding 
started an hour ago and has not stopped. Where is the bleed most likely to be from?
questions.explanation:
The bleeding is most likely from the Little's area. Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of 
epistaxis in children and young adults. 328 
Sold by @itachibot Factors that increase the risk of epistaxis in children when compared to adults, include the habit 
of nose picking and increased friability of mucosa due to frequent upper respiratory tract 
infections.

questions.question: Question 2: Where is Little’s area situated?
questions.explanation: Little’s area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule.

questions.question:
Question 3: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On 
examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following 
arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.explanation:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the 
septum). The contributing arteries are as follows: • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch 
of the external carotid artery. • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The 
facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

questions.question:

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
questions.explanation:
The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic 
division of the internal carotid artery. Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows: 2 – Sphenopalatine artery 3 – Greater palatine artery 4 – Superior labial artery 2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery. The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries. 330 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled, chronic hypertension was rushed to 
the casualty after he had an episode of coughing out frank blood. On further evaluation, a 
diagnosis of posterior epistaxis, secondary to hypertension, was made. What is the site of the 
blood vessel most likely to be involved in this case?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause for posterior epistaxis is arterial and the vessel involved is the 
sphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and is 
also sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension 
and coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds. Note: Most common vessel involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine 
artery and not Woodruff's plexus.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in children?
questions.explanation:
Microtrauma due to nose pricking is the most common cause of epistaxis in children. Other common aetiological associations include upper respiratory tract infections. Note: In children presenting with recurrent epistaxis, bleeding disorders, hereditary hemorrhagic 
telangiectasia, and tumors, etc. have to be ruled out.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients is idiopthic. Other causes are: • Trauma • Coagulopathy 331 
Sold by @itachibot • Tumor - high suspicion in elderly patients presenting with epistaxis • Infection • Medication Note: Due to the failure of studies to establish a causal relationship between hypertension and 
epistaxis, hypertension is now considered an associated risk factor and not a cause. Risk factors associated with epistaxis are weather changes and alcohol consumption.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge which is 
blood-stained. Which of the following is the most likely cause? 325 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In a child presenting with persistent unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, which is 
blood-stained, the most likely cause is a foreign body. Foreign body can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and subsequent superimposed infection 
which causes malodorous discharge. It may often be blood-stained. Option B: Atrophic rhinitis usually starts at puberty and mainly presents with nasal obstruction 
and foul smell from the nose. Epistaxis occurs only after the removal of crusts. Option C: Epistaxis is a rare manifestation of polyps. Option D: Unilateral nasal angiofibroma also presents as painless, progressive unilateral 
nasal obstruction, often associated with epistaxis and rhinorrhea. But it is more common in the 
adolescent age group.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little 
forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to 
control epistaxis. Other options: Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional 
Vertigo). 332 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large hole 
provides a good oral airway. Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose 
and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or 
to clear the ears and sinuses.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 60-year-old woman came to the casualty with a history of an episode of spontaneous 
epistaxis yesterday night. On examination, her BP was 200/110, and there was no active 
bleeding from the nose. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing 
this case?
questions.explanation:
The most appropriate next step is observation and blood pressure management as there is no 
active bleeding from the nose. 333 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of 
spontaneous nose bleeds over the past two weeks, each requiring medical attention. After 
evaluating the patient, the ENT surgeon recommended endoscopic artery ligation to prevent 
further episodes. Which of the following arteries is most commonly ligated in this procedure?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of refractory posterior epistaxis. The artery which 
is most commonly ligated in a case of refractory posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery. Posterior epistaxis is most commonly seen in older age groups. The bleeding is spontaneous, often 
due to hypertension, and is severe, requiring hospitalization. Refractory epistaxis is defined as 
recurrent or persistent bleeding after appropriate packing or multiple episodes of epistaxis during 
a short period, each requiring medical attention. Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior 
bleed. Therefore, transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred 
method. It is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate. Anterior epistaxis

questions.question:
Question 13: As a first-year resident, you have scrubbed in to assist for a maxillary artery ligation 
procedure on a patient with intractable epistaxis. After opening the posterior wall of the 
maxillary sinus, the surgeon asks you to ligate the maxillary artery. Where would you ligate 
the artery at?
questions.explanation:
The maxillary artery is ligated at the pterygopalatine fossa (sphenopalatine fossa) situated behind 
the maxillary sinus’s posterior wall. The internal maxillary artery is accessed transantrally via a Caldwell-Luc approach. After the 
posterior sinus wall is removed, the internal maxillary artery and its terminal branches are 
identified and clipped. The posterior sinus wall is then packed with Gelfoam, and the 
gingivobuccal incision is closed. More recently, transoral and transnasal endoscopic approaches 
have also been described.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which artery among the following could be the source of bleeding in a case of epistaxis not 
controlled by external carotid artery ligation?
questions.explanation:
Ethmoidal artery can cause epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation. 335 
Sold by @itachibot The ethmoidal artery is a branch of internal carotid artery, whereas sphenopalatine, greater 
palatine and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if the bleeding is not 
controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidal 
artery. Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis. Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It 
is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases. Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area 
is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site 
for epistaxis in children and young adults. The four contributing arteries are as follows: • Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in 
turn is a branch of the external carotid artery. • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The 
facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery. Anterior epistaxis

Question 15: 327 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following vessels would you never ligate for the control of recurrent 
spontaneous epistaxis?

options.a: A VDRL positive patient with gumma of the nasal septum
options.b: A patient with lateral madarosis and leonine facies
options.c: A boxer who developed bilateral nasal obstruction after a trauma to the nose
options.d: A patient with growth hormone excess and a large nose.

questions.explanation:
Internal carotid artery is not ligated for controlling epistaxis due to the high percentage of 
cerebral complications and mortality. Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control : • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation 337 
Sold by @itachibot • In case, bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior 
ethmoidal vessels should be ligated. 338
